{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3442062,"name":"Layton","username":"LaytonK737","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/l/aca169/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-10-31T13:06:04.148Z","cooked":"

We made the decision to switch to krakens and swerve drive for the upcoming season but I have never coded kraken or a swerve drive so any sample code somewhere I could use also any advice to make it easier transition for me to get started would be greatly appreciated

Thank you

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":4,"updated_at":"2024-10-31T13:06:04.148Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":418,"reads":185,"readers_count":184,"score":2127.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":474098,"topic_slug":"first-time-kraken-motor-use-and-swerve-drive-use","display_username":"Layton","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":64705,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/first-time-kraken-motor-use-and-swerve-drive-use/474098/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3442063,"name":"","username":"KfirNeuman","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/k/d07c76/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-10-31T13:18:31.019Z","cooked":"

If you are using all CTRE devices I would highly recommend trying out the CTRE swerve. It is incredibly fast to set up, you could probably have a drivable swerve within an hour. On top of that it has some pretty good features like high frequency odometry.

The main disadvantage is that it is a closed library. You can’t change it or add your own features directly into the code, you need to create a wrapper.

I would suggest starting with CTRE to see that you can get the swerve working and start playing around with things. Then try look at some other libraries like YAGSL, or create your own so that you have more options for customization.

You have a whole lot of options to choose from:

CTRE Swerve

This is the official swerve API from CTRE. It’s designed for ease and consistency, running closed loops directly on hardware and using CTRE features. As @KfirNeuman mentioned, this is a great place to start.

YAGSL

A community-developed swerve drive library that offers many helpful features like auto-alignment and aim-at-target functionality. It’s an excellent choice if your team has some programming experience and wants high-level features for your swerve drive.

Base Falcon Swerve

A basic swerve drive skeleton for CTRE components. It includes only essential features, so if you’re up for more geeking, this could be a good option.

AdvancedSwerveDrive

Swerve Drive with AdvantageKit for teams that want to do Log Replay. This is best explored after you’ve gained familiarity with basic swerve drive implementations.
